Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Detection and Classification Problems in Online Information Graphs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Online Social Networks (OSN) such as Facebook, Twitter, as well as a plethora of online datasets, such as Wikipedia and US government?s DATA.GOV initiative are becoming the repositories of knowledge and discussion for the future. These OSNs and online datasets all share the common feature that they can be thought of as ?Online Information Graphs? (OIG), in the sense that the information embedded in them has a natural graph structure, such as Facebook?s graph of ?friends?. This project considers the question of detection and classification of real-world events using these Online Information Graphs from a communication theoretic viewpoint, by using the graph to specify a Bayes prior. As more and more data is made freely available on the internet, utilizing it to extract information becomes important for society, which is the main goal of the project. For example, Open Government data can improve governance, if inferences applicable to society can be made from it.

The questions about OIG that are being investigated are; defining and learning suitable models for the Bayes prior of the OIG, defining various detection and classification problems on OIGs, designing detection algorithms for large OIGs, analyzing detector performance, and engineering the information graph to improve detection. The research is partly experimental (e.g., exploring real-world datasets) and partly theoretical (e.g., analyzing detector performance), and so, intellectual contributions will be made in both categories. Algorithms are being designed to operate on these models, for graph structures typical in OSN-type datasets. The research uses analytical techniques from communication theory, adapted to probabilistic graphical models, to predict error performance and to engineer the networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Online Social Networks (OSN) such as Facebook, Twitter, as well as a plethora of online datasets, such as Wikipedia and US government’s DATA.GOV initiative are becoming the repositories of knowledge and discussion for the future. These OSNs and online datasets all share the common feature that they can be thought of as ‘Online Information Graphs’, in the sense that the information embedded in them has a natural graph structure. This project considered the question of detection and classification of real-world events using these Online Information Graphs from a communication theoretic viewpoint, by using the graph to specify a Bayes prior. The questions that were investigated are; defining and learning suitable models for the Bayes prior, defining various detection and classification problems, designing detection algorithms for large information graphs and analyzing detector performance.

The most important problem considered was that of majority sentiment detection (and its variants), using noisy measurements. To understand this, consider a pollster who polls likely voters on their preferred vote in an upcoming election. However, assume that voters may lie with some probability (a phenomenon called ‘preference falsification’). What is the probability that the pollster correctly predicts the outcome of the election? Some thought shows that the same model applies to the issue of sentiment detection of citizens towards some civil topic, or attractiveness of consumers to a particular product in the marketplace. Can noisy measurements result in accurate prediction in these cases?

 

Intellectual Merit: A basic result in statistics states that if a single binary variable is being measured repeatedly, the probability of incorrectly guessing its value goes to 0, as more and more measurements are made. However, the project discovered that this intuition does not apply to majority sentiment detection. In fact, even though a single binary variable is being measured (the sentiment of the majority of the users), the probability of incorrectly guessing its value may be fairly high (see Fig. 3 in publication [1]). The so-called ‘law of large numbers’ does not apply to this case. On the other hand, if the users are connected by a social network (see Fig. 1 in publication [1]), so that connected users (‘friends’) share similar (but not the same) beliefs, the probability of incorrectly guessing the majority sentiment can, in fact, go to zero exponentially quickly in the size of the social network. Even more strange effects can occur, wherein for a fixed social network, as the connection strength between friends diminishes, the probability of incorrect guess can rise from essentially zero, to fairly high values (see Fig. 4 in publication [1]). Thus, the type of social network, and the strength of connections of friends in the network has a strong impact on the problem of measuring sentiments/votes. These results are presented in the publications [1],[2] listed below.

 

Broader Impact: As more and more data is made freely available on the internet, utilizing it to extract information becomes important for society, which was the main goal of the project. For example, Open Government data can improve governance, if inferences applicable to society can be made from it. The theoretical results from the project can potentially impact fields as disparate as statistics, engineering and social science, since the model and problem analyzed applies to all those fields. The award supported graduate students, who were trained to span the intersection of disparate fields (communication theory, social networks). Presentations detailing the results from this research were made at various conferences and the ideas developed were incorporated in graduate courses at Carnegie Mellon.

 

[1] Tian Tong and Rohit Negi, “Asymptotic performance analysis of majority sentiment detection in online social networks,” in Proc. 54th Annual Allerton Conference on Communication, Control, and Computing, pp. 1291–1297, Allerton, IL, Sept. 2016. A draft copy is available at https://arxiv.org/abs/1611.04654

[2] Tian Tong and Rohit Negi, “Supermajority sentiment detection with external influence in large social networks,” in Proc. 55th Annual Allerton Conference on Communication, Control, and Computing, Allerton, IL, Oct. 2017.
